reviewText: And, incidentally, a superb performance from Charlton Heston. If you've read the book, you know the story. If you haven't, then what you have here is a classic pirate tale that is well told, and unobtrusively directed.I had digitized an old VHS tape, and I pre-ordered this as soon as I heard it was coming out on DVD. Assuming the master tape is in good condition, an officially released DVD will be better than any old VHS transfer. Well, there has been some remastering; the colors are much more vibrant, and the edges are cleaner. The over-all picture, though, is still a bit grainy - particularly in shots which feature a large expanse of solid color. For instance, in the very opening shots, which have a large expanse of grey horizon: there are a number of speckles and dots. If you sit far enough away from the screen, they probably won't be noticeable. The quality varies throughout the movie, but is always better than my old VHS version. Plus, the movie is presented in widescreen, which is better than my old VHS, which was in 4:3 aspect ratio.So, definitely worth the upgrade. Don't be surprised by some lack of picture quality - but don't don't let this hold you back from enjoying this awesome film.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Treasure Island, 1989 filmThe story begins with a small boat on the ocean with two men in it. One man comes ashore with a small chest. He stops at a small inn to find lodging. Billy Bones spends his days looking out to sea. He warns Jim Hawkins against a one-legged sailor. Doctor Livesey shows his character. One day another man enters the inn; he is "Black Dog". He talks to Billy Bones about a chart. They draw cutlasses and fight, the stranger runs off. Next a blind man comes by to meet Billy Bones, and hands him a paper: the black spot. [How did a blind man find his way to this inn?] There is drama when more men burst in at ten o'clock! Jim and his mother run away to hide in the woods. Four armed horsemen arrive to drive away the intruders. They saw a strange schooner in the bay. Doctor Livesey brings Jim and his map to Squire Trelawney. The map marks the treasure of Captain Flynn.The Squire will hire a ship and crew in Bristol to sail to this island. Jim says farewell to his mother. Squire found a man, Long John Silver, who will help him to gather a crew. [It is hard to find good help.] John Silver orders a man to move so Jim can sit. Jim tells about the events at the inn. Captain Smolett learns about his crew. The ship prepares to sail. They run into a storm, Jim gets seasick. The first mate Arrow was lost in the night, he must have gone overboard. Jim learns seamanship. Inside, Jim overhears the talk of John Silver to Israel Hands. "Dead men tell no tales." They hear the cry "Land ho!". Jim tells the Captain, the Squire, and the Doctor what he learned. Forewarned is forearmed. Silver's men have hidden muskets. Jim jumps from the longboat and runs ashore. Back on board the pirates attack the officers, but fail to take over the ship. Jim finds Ben Gunn in the woods, he tells Jim about his past (marooned on this island). The good guys decide the blockhouse in the woods is a better refuge than aboard ship.The good guys leave the ship in a small boat. The pirates aboard fire the cannon at their boat. The pirates on land run after the good guys to attack them, but they find a refuge in the blockhouse. They are outnumbered. But fever from the swamp can even the odds. John Silver offers them a deal for the treasure map; it is refused. The pirates bring the cannon ashore to attack the blockhouse. Then they attack the blockhouse, but are repulsed. In the night Jim leaves secretly to return to the ship. The two pirates aboard drink and quarrel. Jim sails the ship to the North inlet and beaches her. Israel Hands attacks him, but Jim flees up the mast and reloads his pistols. Jim defends himself, and Hands falls into the sea. When Jim returns to the blockhouse he finds new tenants! Jim boasts about what he did.There is dissension among the pirates. They vote to depose John Silver as captain. Silver produces the map and is reelected! The Doctor comes to treat their sick. The pirates follow the map and the pointers on the ground. [How was the treasure carried on that difficult path?] They hear a voice; is it a ghost? But they only find a hole in the ground! The good guys ambush the pirates. They go to Ben Gunn's cave to see the gold and jewelry he recovered, and sail back to England. What will happen to John Silver now? He waves goodbye. A small boat cannot be caught under those wind conditions.Was Long John Silver the first "lovable rogue" in literature? A bad man with acts of goodness. This version played down the bungling of Squire Trelawney, a man of inherited wealth. Compare him to Doctor Livesey or Captain Smolett. Note how the pirated elected or deposed their leader, and received an equal share of the wealth. What would they get on a regular merchantman or naval vessel?

reviewText: A terrific telling of Robert Louis Stevenson's adventure, Christian Bale as the young Jim Hawkins and Charlton Heston as Long John Silver are both superb, and head a great cast: Richard Johnson, Oliver Reed, Clive Wood, and Julian Glover among the many actors that bring the story to life. Filmed in Jamaica, as well as the Hispaniola, a beauty of a ship, the scenery and cinematography by Robert Steadman are marvelous.The soundtrack is by Paddy Moloney and performed by The Cheiftains, and is also very effective.Christian Bale, so moving two years earlier in "Empire of the Sun", is here courageous and strong; only fourteen at the time this was made, he is quite remarkable, and Heston does a turn as the bad guy, and is sensational as old wily Silver, saying things like "I'll have yer liver for breakfast !".Director Fraser Heston, who made his cinematic debut as the infant Moses in the 1956 "The Ten Commandments" his father starred in, keeps the pacing fast and though there are a lot of sword fights and shooting, it is mostly sound effects and there is very little in the way of gore, making the film suitable for children. The dialect of the sailors sounds foreign at first, but one soon gets used to it.Originally made for television, this is rousing, exceptional story-telling, that will keep one's interest for numerous viewings.Total running time is 132 minutes.

reviewText: This film was well researched, and acted.  The idomatic forms of 18th century English are well larded with words which require a dictionary for their meaning. An example is Long John speaks of eating a Plumduff, which is a raisin pudding boiled in a bag.  I did not find any weak points in the acting or direction.  I have waited what seems like an age for this film to be transfered to DVD.  Rather than say it was "well worth the wait"; I think I should say "...it's about bloody time"!

reviewText: One day a mysterious person comes to stay at an inn ran by a boy and his mother.  It is obvious that this stranger led a rough sea going life.  What was not obvious is that events with his previous associates would eventually lead to adventure and "Treasure Island."Of course nothing can replace the book "Treasure Island" by Robert Louis Stevenson.  However this movie comes closest. I also have a copy of Treasure Island (1934) because that is what I watched as a kid and thought of it as a classic. But Wallace Beery can not come near Charlton Heston as Long John Silver.What you do not want to waste your time on is Treasure Island (1950) with Bobby Driscoll. This version is chopped up. People are missing. And the story is so sweet that you don't recognize the plot.If you are or have kids you do not want to miss "Muppets Treasure Island" with Tim Curry (1996).

reviewText: Charlton Heston, as I've said before, is notable for playing larger-than-life characters, but mostly they're heroes.  This time he takes on a larger-than-life villain--Long John Silver, the true star of Robert Louis Stevenson's classic novel.  When young Jim Hawkins (Christian Bale) and his mother (Isla Blair) accept "seafaring man" Billy Bones (Oliver Reed) as a guest at their inn, they don't have an inkling of what they're putting themselves in for.  Bones, it seems, was a member of Captain Flint's pirate crew and has in his possession a map to Flint's treasure--for which his surviving crewmen Blind Pew (Christopher Lee) and Black Dog (John Benfield) are quite willing to commit murder.  Inadvertantly Jim gets hold of the map, and sensibly takes it to Dr. Livesey (Julian Glover), who in turn gets Squire Trelawney (Richard Johnson) to fit out a ship to go in search of the hoard.  What they don't know is that Pew and Black Dog weren't the only remaining members of Flint's crew, and Silver, the worst of them all--the only man Flint himself feared--is on the loose and hunting.Most of the cast is English, which is as it should be, but American Heston manages to fit himself in very well--and it's obvious by his dialect that he's studied Robert Newton's portrayal of the character (inTreasure Island).  Like Stevenson, he makes Silver not only plausible and understandable but almost likeable--and at the same time tough, ruthless, and afraid only of hanging.  The costuming, setting, and props are all obviously the result of careful research, and the pace holds your attention for over two hours.  I was delighted to find this TV-special available on DVD at last.

reviewText: I recently watched a later version with Eddy Izzard as Long John.  It was good, but Heston sets the bar too high.  Heston is not the only strength of this film.  The other characters are believable, and the actors do a good job.  In both versions you get the sense that while Silver likes Jim he won't hesitate to slit his throat.  It is a complex relationship, well explored.  If you want a version of this classic tale, this is the one to get.

reviewText: I came across this title in July, a couple weeks after reading the Robert Louis Stevenson classic for the first time. Upon finishing the book, I immediately turned to Amazon to find a movie version. But the only ones ever made, it appeared, were silly Disney adaptations that the user reviews warned me off of. A few days later, when this remake popped up onto an Amazon movers-and-shakers list, and immediately elicited gushing reviews, I thought I had found a diamond in the rough. Charlton Heston? Christian Bale? A musical score by the Chieftains? A script that hews closely to the book? Filmed on location in England and Jamaica AND on the Bounty, a detailed replica built in 1962 for another movie? Sold!But this movie is no gem. It suffers from a number of fatal flaws.The first, which is immediately apparent, is the lack of detail in the sets. The background in each scene just looks empty. Many, many scenes are super closeups of whatever character is speaking at the time. The character's mug shot fills nearly the entire screen, as though the director is mindful of the empty set behind his actor.Another flaw: Bad makeup jobs. The character Blind Pew, especially, is made to look more like an extra in a really bad monster movie than a blind pirate. Long John Silver looks more like a millionaire at a costume party than the most feared pirate of the time.Then there is the timing. There seems to be a delay to a few scenes, and though it is only a split second, you can imagine that the actors had just been standing there waiting for the director to yell, "Aaaaand action!" Also, there is little rhythm to the dialog, a shame considering the dialog in the book, the rhythm of the book, rang with so much magic.The movie seems not to have choreographed the sword fights, and the actors appear not to have even learned how to properly wield a sword. There is one close-up of Long John Silver fending off another pirate with his sword. It's just a supercloseup of him waving his arm back and forth across his body. All the action scenes are unfortunately laughable.The acting itself is another problem. With the exception of Christian Bale's Jim Hawkins and Charlton Heston's Long John Silver, all the other characters use exaggerated styles of speaking, facial expressions and gesturing that make them look more like comic fools than cutthroat pirates and determined treasure huntersThere were intangible screw-ups. A fight scene that was supposed to be taking place at 10 o'clock at night is waged in broad daylight. And how to describe the scene in which Jim Hawkins, who is supposed to be a little boy, is supposed to fall into an apple barrel? Christian Bale at the time was not little. So the director had Bale hoist himself up and into an oversize barrel feet-first, on top of the apples, then bend at the knees so he could reach down and pick up one of the apples he was standing on. It would have been easy and natural for the character just to reach into the barrel and pick up an apple. But for the story to move along, Jim had to be unseen, inside the barrel, so he could eavesdrop on a conversation that is important to the plot.The biggest flaw, however, is the lack of suspense. Director Fraser Heston somehow managed to take a story that drips with adventure and suspense and drain it of both.This movie has one thing going for it: the Chieftains score. It really is terrific. But if you want to truly relive this tale of adventure through a performance that does it justice, please allow me to suggest an audible.com narration:[...]This audible edition truly brings the words of Robert Louis Stevenson to life.

reviewText: Turner Home Entertainment's "Treasure Island" is a wonderfully entertaining movie, with a young Christian Bale (Batman Begins) as Jim Hawkins and the legendary Charleton Heston as Long John Silver in Robert Louis Stevenson's classic adventure story about pirates and buried treasure.  Originally released as a television movie, it has a very believable and mostly British cast, location shooting in England and the Caribbean, excellent production values, and a superb score by the Chieftains.The story begins at the old Admiral Benbow Inn, kept by Jim Hawkins and his widowed mother, where one day the mysterious Captain Billy Bones takes up residence.  Bones, a crusty old drunk, takes a bit of a shine to young Jim, but turns out to be all trouble when his murderous former shipmates catch up with him, looking for a map showing where the pirate Captain Flint buried his treasure.  In the ensuing fight, Jim gets away with the map, and is soon off on a treasure hunt, courtesy of the local squire and doctor.  Unfortunately, Captain Flint's old crew are also hunting for treasure, and Jim will have many adventures at sea and on a mysterious island before the matter of the treasure is finally settled.The movie generally follows the book, with a few variations.  Christian Bale is perfect as the brave young Hawkins, while Heston absolutely nails Long John Silver.  There is some violence and several tense moments, but also some moral lessons.  This movie can be served up as family entertainment for anyone old enough to read the book; very highly recommended.

reviewText: Although the 1934 and 1950 (Disney) versions of "Treasure Island" are both quite good and still worth watching, I believe that this is the definitive version of the timeless story of piracy and high seas adventure.  Charleton Heston is the best Long John Silver that I have ever seen on film ("Them that dies will be the luckey ones!"), better than Robert Newton or Wallace Beery.  The supporting cast is excellent.  I can only imagine that acting luminaries such as Oliver Reed and Christopher Lee must have had great fun making this movie.  Christian Bale was excellent as Jim Hawkins, although possibly a year or two old for the role.  But why carp?  Very few liberties are taken with the original story in this film version and that is good because the original book is hard to improve upon.  One of the most striking aspects about the Fraser Heston version of "Treasure Island" are the remarkable visual effects and the apparent care given to recreate the look and feel of N. C. Wyeth's famous illustrations of Robert Louis Stephenson's book.  Possibly some of the language and violence may not be suitable for young children, but have you ever heard real sailors talk?  This movie is no more violent than the daily fare on CNN.  I have a videotape of this film recorded off of television but I would love to buy a copy if it were on DVD.
summary: "...even Flint was afeard of Long John Silver!"

reviewText: This version of Treasure Island in my opinion, is the best one out there.  A great cast was assembled and scenes were remarkable to portray this epic story.  Charleton Heston plays a great role as Long John Silver, but he is one of many great actors who did well in this movie.  Viewers see how Jim Hawkins (Bale) acquired the map from Billy Bones and then how he got swept up in the quest for treasure.  Besides the scenery and the action, the Chieftains added great music for the soundtrack.I grew up seeing the Disney film and thought it was okay, but when I saw this version, I was blown away.  I recommend this movie to anyone who likes action and adventure films.

reviewText: I remember watching this made for TV movie when it first aired in 1990, and I fell in love with it.  I wore down the VHS that was released and am so glad this is finally coming to DVD (thank you Amazon for the alerts!).  I think this is hands down the best adaptation of the classic book I have ever seen.  And, this looks and feels like a major motion picture, rather than a TV movie.  The cast is phenomenal, and the production values are high.  Charlton Heston completely disappears into the role of Long John Silver, and makes viewers sympathize and even root for the scurrilous pirate.  I have found that the kid cast as Jim Hawkins is usually the week link in film versions of Treasure Island.  However, Christian Bale shows his potential and then some here.  He easily stands toe-to-toe with the veteran actors surrounding him, and embodies the central role of the film.  Even small parts, like Blind Pew, stand out with the incomparable Christopher Lee in the role.Though not as violent as some films, this would easily earn a PG, or even PG-13 rating.  So parents should keep that in mind.  It's a little bloody, befitting pirates that can and do commit murder (one character is shown with his throat slit).  There are a few "battle" scenes and characters get shot and die.  Overall, this is a rousing adventure story, with top notch acting, great locations and a strong score.  Highly recommended, and I suggest families read the book and then watch the film together - great way to connect!As to the DVD, this is a fairly bare bones edition. It does have a director's commentary, but there are no other extras.  I would have liked some featurettes on the actors, the book, or the time period, but I still won't hesitate to recommend this.  The picture quality is crisp for a 20+ year old tv movie.  One odd thing though - the DVD does not have a scene selection menu, only "play movie."  Again, not a biggie since I can fast forward or rewind, but still unusual.  Overall, the film is fantastic and easily worth the retail price (which Amazon has discounted).UPDATE: A commenter asked about subtitles & I realized others might appreciate that info as well.  The DVD has Enlish Subtitles for the Hearing Impaired, as well as Spanish and French substitles.

reviewText: the greatest film version of Robert Louis Stevenson's classic, period!! and for one very simple reason...to this day we tend to think of TREASURE ISLAND as a children's story, possibly because it's a child's first-person account. (also, i recall reading somewhere that Stevenson had just gotten married, and had written the book chiefly as a gift to his new stepson.) not that there's anything especially wrong with that approach - it's resulted in some entertaining films (of which MUPPET TREASURE ISLAND is my personal favorite) - but let's face it: just how likely are pirates to of been the whimsical sort of characters suggested by Robert Newton's characterisation?at the other end of that extreme, of course, is PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN, which gave us one broad but exciting installment and several increasingly over-the-top but decreasingly comprehensible follow-ups.somewhere in the middle you'll find this delightful little film. under the direction of his son, Long John Silver turned out to be Charlton Heston's best role since PLANET OF THE APES. and he's hardly the only legend who managed to get in on the fun. he's amply aided by the likes of Oliver Reed, Richard Johnson, Julian Glover, and Christian Bale. even Christopher Lee contributes, which is so surprizing because he plays the iconic but frankly scanty part of Blind Pew.co-stars who should be just as much housegold names include James Coyle, Pete Postlethwaite, and one Clive Wood, who's commaning take on Captain Smollett is no less gripping than Heston's Silver. it seems like every successful film features at least one towering performance that gets lost in the shuffle of and doesn't get the applaud it merits. in ths case it's Clive Wood's.(come to think if it, maybe it's Fraser Heston, who's tight script and tighter direction made the whole thing possible. it's not quite a shame, but pretty close, that his legacy seems limited to this and the other film he and his father made for the Turner Network, the flawed but entertaining Sherlock Holmes caper THE CRUCIFER OF BLOOD.but i digress...)and the characters portrayed by this faultless cast are what logic dictates pirates were: dirty, ruthless, greedy bastards in the first degree. of course they can't go too far in that direction: it's still an X-marks-the-spot saga. the device is certainly romantic, but considering that pirates were basically mercenaries, how much of their treasure do you suppose was actually buried? but this film gives an even balance. we are mercifully spared, for instance, that reknown seafaring non-sequiter "Arrrrr!"the prinicle advantage is probably the faithfulness to the source material: even most of the dialogue is strait from Stevenson's pen. i've argued against the notion of the book always outoing the movie, because i've seen a number of movie where it turned out the filmmaker's ideas and variations strengthened the story and even made it make more sense. (see my review of 20,000 LEAGUES UNDER THE SEA.) well, like so much other phenomena, sometimes that happens and sometimes it doesn't.if i have any regrets about this film, it's that it was made for television. this is a lavish, towering production that deserved a shot at the Silver Screen. oh well.in short, set sail, hoist the mailsail, and all that jazz.

reviewText: While Disney set the standard for Treasure Island by which all other versions are judged, TNT's take on the classic R.L. Stevenson tale is by far the best.  Everything from the locations, action sequences, acting, pacing, and cinematography are first rate.  Christian Bale plays a sturdy Jim Hawkins.  You actually believe he can pull of some of the adventures that he does in the film.  If Robert Newton will forever be the ideal of Long John Silver, Charlton Heston comes a close second playing the role with both physical power and deviousness....this guy is always calculating the odds.  The supporting characters are first rate....how can you go wrong with Oliver Reed as Billy Bones, Christopher Lee as Blind Pew, Julian Glover as the doctor and Peter Postlethwaite as George Merry? For a TV movie this one sure has a lot of star power!  You can also tell that no one mailed in their performances.....everyone seems to be having a grand old time.The film score by the Chieftains turns the movie from great to transcendent (if you like boyhood adventures) and some of the set shots are like something from a Wyeth painting.  I'm not a big advocate of buying up movies for the home, but this is one to buy and keep....it really is that good.

reviewText: I bought the video tape in 1991 with very little information other than that The Cheiftans played the soundtrack. The movie took the top of my head off! Surprising, but as it turned out, masterful casting, superlative performances and that stunning soundtrack--in no time it was a family favorite and we sang its praises to the point of alienation of friends and family, but it never lost its appeal. I have been among the hoarde of fans on IMDB and visiting the Turner Network Television site petitioning for its release to DVD quite literally for years and now its happened!  And next month the complete series of Barney Miller! This is really going to be great!
summary: There is simply not a better version made than this!!!

reviewText: I was hooked on this film from the first time I saw it on television almost 10 years ago. I had never actually read the book, but it didn't matter. From the opening sequence of Billy Bones (a very excellent Oliver  Reed)'s arrival at the Admiral Benbow, through young Jim Hawkins (the even  more excellent and underrated actor Christian Bale)'s adventure on the high  seas in search for buried treasure, all the way up to the climactic battles  between the good guys and the pirates led by the fearful Long John Silver  (Charleton Heston, in what I consider his best role ever!), this film is  nonstop action, adventure, and great fun!  It has a great plot, great  characters, and even some comical moments. It will make you want to pick up  the book and read it all over again. Every person of every age and gender  can appreciate this movie. It is an essential modern classic.
summary: A brilliant adaptation, definitely worth owning!

reviewText: Maybe my expectations are too high. I thought this would be much better than some of the other versions of T.I. I'll admit, the music was OUTSTANDING.(I always appreciate that Celtic touch) But some of the performances were soggy. Christian Bale stunk as Jim Hawkins. It was pretty obvious that his inclusion was for the "teeny-boppers", but he has all the appeal of an empty room. He was almost as bad as Jackie Cooper from the MGM version with Wallace Beery. Heston was a strange choice for Silver since his accent was awful. Granted Robert Newton's bastardized Irish brogue was pure cartoon, but Newton WAS British and the Disney version was aimed at KIDS. Heston was much more menacing than Beery or other screen Silvers. I enjoyed Christopher Lee as "Blind Pew". It is really refreshing to see him in a non-Dracula role. Oliver Reed was acceptable as Billy Bones. As far as staying true to the story, well, it was closer than that wretched version with Orson Wells. (Arrr-ful) Clothing, props and weaponry were much better than most, so history buffs and reenactors will enjoy it. Most American actors have difficulty doing Welsh, British and Irish accents and it comes across in this version. Treasure Island will always be a classic book, in spite of Hollywood's vandalism.
summary: One to Have if you like pirate flicks

reviewText: The Disney-version is still the best, but this is excellent too, and worth watching even if you know the story. Disney's Robert Newton will always be the quintessential / perfect pirate with his squinting eye. The Disney version captures the charm of the story.The version with Jackie Cooper as Jim Hawkins ties for second-place, and is also worth watching for the character acting.This version is more realistic. The pirates are more vicious. You feel more the impending danger. You also see more clearly the importance of Jim Hawkins foiling the pirates at key points, and the bitter frustration of the pirates. In the other versions; Long John Silver plays both sides to keep his options open; but here we see Long John Silver one-sided until the moment his plan has become hopelessly foiled. In other versions; you feel Long John Silver genuinely likes the boy, Jim Hawkins, but here you sense Long John Silver would readily kill Jim Hawkins, but befriends him only for seeing what the other pirates do not see; they are in a jam, and Jim Hawkins is the only way out. Filmed on location in the Caribbean in color.A story in the 1700's starting in England. Some good-guys set sail with a map to hunt pirate treasure. Unknowingly many of their crew are blood-thirsty pirates.

reviewText: Forget all the other versions of R. L. Stevenson's classic adventure tale - this is by far the best!  Drawn very closely from the book with dialogue lifted straight out, this production is excellent in all respects, from the  atmospheric music by the Chieftains and effective (though brief) cameos by  Christopher Lee and the late Oliver Reed, to the excellent location  photography.  It doesn't get any better than this!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Brilliant, wonderful adaptation of R.L. Stevenson's classic seafaring tale -- this is beyond doubt THE best pirate film to have yet been made. Bar none. If you don't clap this one to your heart, ye be a false-sworn landlubber, by thunder, and here's my affydavy on that!  Worth SIX stars if it were possible to award a bonus.The DVD release of this astonishingly good film is something fans have clamored for since the dawn of the digital era.  Tremendous cast, sterling production values, brilliant cinematography, rousing musical score, crack screenplay, and vibrant performances make this an enduring classic.I have not noticed any issues concerning the picture clarity. Some of the scenes are shot in natural indoor light, making them perforce darker than scenes shot in brilliant sunshine. The slight picture cropping some have remarked on is not noticeable and the widescreen presentation  as shown in overseas theatres is probably to be preferred. (It's a pity this wasn't given a theatrical release domestically; just too ahead of its time, pre-Captain Sparrow, I suppose.)The only bum note I can spot concerns the subtitles.  The subtitler appears to have relied on their ears rather than a script, and the subtitles are full of errors, sometimes hilarious malapropisms, when the English accents or the nautical slang confused the transcriber.Postscript: I  want to put in a plug for the greatest pirate film to star a swashbuckling female, "Anne of the Indies" (aka "The Pirate Queen"), which has sadly never been released to home video in No. America but has aired on cable TV and is available on PAL Region 2 DVD (as Die Piratenkonigin) in Germany. If you have an all-region DVD player, you should run, not walk, to Amazon Deutschland and pick this up. It's the original English-language release, just switch off any German language options or subtitling. Jean Peters stars as Captain Anne Providence and gives her all in a wonderfully engaging, if corny, color production from about 1951. Peters is genuinely athletic, beautiful, and obviously loved this role. Anne of the Indies beats all other pirate queens hands down.Now, if only they'd make a film about Grania O'Malley, we'd be splicin' the mainbrace!
summary: Weigh anchor for thrills and excitement!

reviewText: TNT's version of Treasure Island left an indelible mark on my young impressionable mind. I'd already read the novel several times, but seeing Stevenson's novel come to life on the small screen was an incredible journey. This was my first introduction to the Chieftains and Irish music (the majority of the Treasure Island soundtrack can be found on Film Cuts), and soon after, I bought my first tin whistle and learned to play the Treasure Island theme.The stellar cast is headed by Charlton Heston as the roguishly charming Long John Silver and a young Christian Bale fresh off ofEmpire of the Sun (Snap Case Packaging)]. Other notables include a cameo by horror master Christopher Lee as Blind Pew, Julian Glover as Dr. Livesey and Pete Postlethwaite as George Merry. The cast is largely composed of classically trained British theater actors and it shows.The film's sense of authenticity is also earned through its period costumes, makeup, and furnishings, elaborate sets and using the actual HMS Bounty rather than a model (I became obsessed with tall ships after seeing this). The film was a combination of soundstage and location footage filmed in England (Cornwall, Buckinghamshire, Devon) and Jamaica that fused seamlessly to transport the viewer from prim and proper English country estates to the sweltering, malaria-infested jungles of Treasure Island.The screenplay stays fairly faithful to the original novel; Long John is played to perfection by Heston, who infuses his role with a charming smile hiding a shark's voracious grin. Silver is not a cutesy one as played by Wallace Beery in Treasure Island; rather, he's as cutthroat as the shifty crew. Bale's Jim goes from a wide-eyed boy who'd never seen the world to one who's forced to come of age quickly and brutally at the hands of Silver and his crew. The screenplay plays up the interactions between Jim, Dr. Livesey, Squire Trelawney, and Captain Smollett (Clive Wood puts in a heroic turn with a fierce, I'm -going-down-with-my-ship-and-pirates-be-damned pride), and Silver and his crew.The pacing keeps things moving along briskly and efficiently, and the film's haunting ending (with a voiceover by Bale) will stay in your mind long after you see this. Of the several versions I've seen of Treasure Island, this was the most authentic and enjoyable, and it's long overdue to make an appearance on DVD. Forget Jack Sparrow; these are real, down-and-dirty swashbucklers. There are no CGI effects; only real tall ships, rusty cutlasses, and the glitter of gold and greed. The haunting score by the Chieftains (Reel Music Film Scores) still haunts my dreams to this day.
summary: "Wild horses couldn't drag me back to that accursed place..."

reviewText: I ordered this movie on the strength of reviews by other Amazon members and I was not disappointed. Quite frankly, this is as good as it gets.While I understand how some strict Christian folk might struggle a little with some of the (by modern standards) minor profanities, this version is just dark enough, just rough and tumble enough to convey the magic of the original novel.Anybody who has read Under The Black Flag by David Cordingly - a superbly detailed history of piracy, which I obtained from Amazon.com - will realize that even this movie's depiction of real pirates has been consciously sanitized.Chuck Heston's mastery makes this the ultimate Treasure Island, and the supporting cast was brilliantly selected. The immensely gifted Christian Bale has set a standard for the portrayal of Jim Hawkins that will never be surpassed. Likewise, Oliver Reed and Christopher Lee have used their collective genius to immortalize two characters that might otherwise have vanished from your memory as soon as their parts were over.The remaining cast, including Julian Glover, Clive Wood, Isla Blair and Richard Johnson are all similarly perfect for their parts, and the parcel of rogues who comprise the motley crew could not be more believable.Beautifully filmed in Jamaica, every scene is a rich visual delight, especially the ones shot on and around the superbly-maintained HMS Bounty, which passes for the Hispaniola. This movie has had a lot of very good reviews. There's a reason for that. It's brilliant.
summary: Scuttle me bones, it's a classic

reviewText: As a youth I read and reread my copy of 'Treasure Island' over and over. Of the movie versions I have seen, this one most closelyduplicates the images that the book created in my mind's eye. Christian Bale as Jim Hawkins excels as the wide-eyed youth, suddenly thrust into the exciting world of sea-faring men and buried treasure. Charlton Heston shines as Long John Silver, the one-legged sea cook who can change at will from smooth talking charmer into a ruthless killer.  It is a coming-of-age story, but also aclassic good-versus-evil story. Well shot, with great scenery and excellent sailing footage.
